title: What to Watch: ‘To All the Boys’ for the Third and Final Time
sub_head: Plus, ‘Clarice’ comes to CBS, Kristen Wiig’s ’Barb & Star Go to Vista Del Mar’ and Metallica gives Netflix’s ‘Crime Scene’ a leg up
body:
Just shy of 100 million people watched The Super Bowl on Sunday, the lowest showing since 2007. What’s more, according to Nielsen, 32% of television sets in use in the U.S. during the game were tuned in to something else. There’s been plenty else to watch. And people have been watching.
In the first full week of the year, for example, more than 2 billion minutes of Netflix’s Cobra Kai and 520 million minutes of Disney+’s “Soul” were streamed, according to a recent report from Nielsen.
Here’s what you could be streaming this week:
(Netflix)
Matt Kaplan started ACE Entertainment to make the kinds of movies that he grew up on but didn’t see getting to theaters any more: John Hughes types targeted squarely at teens and young adults. His company’s breakthrough came with “To All the Boys I’ve Loved Before,” which was released by Netflix in 2018, and based on Jenny Han’s bestselling book of the same name. Like Hughes films “The Breakfast Club” and “Ferris Bueller’s Day Off,” the film went into heavy rotation with its audience, becoming one of Netflix’s most viewed original films.
